review.title: Textual Analysis for Studying Chinese Historical Documents and Literary Novels
review.abstract: We analyzed historical and literary documents in Chinese to gain insights into research issues, and overview our studies which utilized four different sources of text materials in this paper. We investigated the history of concepts and transliterated words in China with the Database for the Study of Modern China Thought and Literature, which contains historical documents about China between 1830 and 1930. We also attempted to disambiguate names that were shared by multiple government officers who served between 618 and 1912 and were recorded in Chinese local gazetteers. To showcase the potentials and challenges of computer-assisted analysis of Chinese literatures, we explored some interesting yet non-trivial questions about two of the Four Great Classical Novels of China: (1) Which monsters attempted to consume the Buddhist monk Xuanzang in the Journey to the West (JTTW), which was published in the 16th century, (2) Which was the most powerful monster in JTTW, and (3) Which major role smiled the most in the Dream of the Red Chamber, which was published in the 18th century. Similar approaches can be applied to the analysis and study of modern documents, such as the newspaper articles published about the 228 incident that occurred in 1947 in Taiwan.

[5] By analyzing the changing collocations of "equality," we confirmed the evolution of the concept of "equality" in Chinese society in three periods: 1898-1900, 1901-1914, and 1915-1924, which was proposed and discussed in [3]. Tables 1 and 2 show the frequency of key words that clashed with the word "equality" in different periods of time. We can see that in different eras, different groups of words were colored with "equality" more often than others, and these different collocation sets and their original contexts implied altogether different concepts of "equality." At one stage, people were striving for equality of the nation, when the Qing dynasty was really weak and invaded by the Western powers. At another phase, inequality between the public and private sectors was disrupted after the ordinary nation had turned into an equality.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUDING REMARKS AND EXTENSIONS
sections.text: The availability of text documents provides a key infrastructure for the digital humanities, but the digitization of data is only a first important step. Building software that helps researchers gather relevant information for further investigation is a necessary part of making the digitized data alive and instrumental. In this paper, we present ourselves with the integrated applications of available data and software for the various types of research problems in history and literature. Our examples show how software tools could help and also shed light on their current limitations. A key prerequisite for the success of historical studies is the reliable and complete capture of documents.
